questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : DEEP LEARNING (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? questions.question_text_1: Which of the following optimization algorithms adapts the learning rate based on the current gradient and the history of gradients?
question_texts: Which of the following optimization algorithms adapts the learning rate based on the current gradient and the history of gradients?

options.option_text: Gradient Descent with exponentially decaying learning rate
Nesterov Accelerated Gradient Descent with step decay

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are regularization technique(S)?
question_texts: Which of the following are regularization technique(S)?

options.option_text: Adding Noise to the inputs or outputs

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following activation function(s) is (are) prone to vanishing gradient problem?
question_texts: Which of the following activation function(s) is (are) prone to vanishing gradient problem?

questions.question_text_1: Which optimization algorithm combines the advantages of RM-Sprop and momentum?
question_texts: Which optimization algorithm combines the advantages of RM-Sprop and momentum?

questions.question_text_1: What is the key reason for the development of adaptive optimization algorithms like RMSprop and Adam?
question_texts: What is the key reason for the development of adaptive optimization algorithms like RMSprop and Adam?

options.option_text: To adapt the learning rate for each parameter dynamically
To reduce the number of layers in deep networks
To decay the initial learning rate

questions.question_text_1: What is the derivative of the Leaky ReLU activation function with respect to its input?
question_texts: What is the derivative of the Leaky ReLU activation function with respect to its input?

options.option_text: 0 for negative inputs, 1 for positive inputs.
1 for negative inputs, 0 for positive inputs.
0.01 for negative inputs, 1 for positive inputs.
0.05 for negative inputs, 1 for positive inputs.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is a common form of regularization that involves adding a penalty proportional to the square of the weights?
question_texts: Which of the following is a common form of regularization that involves adding a penalty proportional to the square of the weights?

questions.question_text_1:
Consider an input image of shape 10×10 with 3 channels of R-G-B, is processed using one of the following neural architectures:  
• Fully-connected layer (FC) with 2 neurons (Note: The input volume is “flattened” into a column vector before being fed into the layer.) • Convolutional layer (CONV) with three filters of size 2 × 2, a stride of 2 is used, and no padding is applied. 
Based on the above data answer the given subquestions.
question_texts:
Consider an input image of shape 10×10 with 3 channels of R-G-B, is processed using one of the following neural architectures:  
• Fully-connected layer (FC) with 2 neurons (Note: The input volume is “flattened” into a column vector before being fed into the layer.) • Convolutional layer (CONV) with three filters of size 2 × 2, a stride of 2 is used, and no padding is applied. 
Based on the above data answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Which architecture has fewer parameters (CONV or FC)?
question_texts: Which architecture has fewer parameters (CONV or FC)?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is/are true about a CONV layer?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is/are true about a CONV layer?

options.option_text: The total number of parameters depends on the depth of the input.
The total number of parameters depends on the padding.
The total number of parameters depends on the number of filters (kernel).
The total number of parameters depends on the stride.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the below deep neural architecture, being applied on an image of size 128 × 128 with 3 channels of R-G-B.
questions.question_text_2: Consider the below deep neural architecture, being applied on an image of size 128 × 128 with 3 channels of R-G-B. Assume i For convolution layers, a stride of 1 is used, and no padding is applied. ii There is no bias associated in any layer just as we did in our course iii Each time we slide the filter we get one value in the output. The resulting output is called a feature map iv Suppose Width, Height and Depth (number of channels) are denoted by W,H,D respectively, then the “Feature map volume” of the tensor (3-D array) = W × H × D (multiplication of W,H,D). Based on the above data answer the given subquestions.
